facts.text: This is Criminal Appeal No. 1 of 1950 by special leave from an order of the High Court of Allahabad.

anchor.surface_text: Criminal Appeal No. 1 of 1950  by special leave from an order of the High Court of Allahabad.

facts.text: Judgment of the Court delivered by KANIA C.J. on March 19, 1951.

anchor.surface_text: 1951. March 19. The judgment of the Court was deliv- ered by KANIA C.J.

facts.text: Allahabad High Court dismissed the revision petition of the appellant against the order of the Special Magistrate refusing to quash the proceedings.

anchor.surface_text: by special leave against an order of the Allahabad High Court dismissing the revision petition of the appellant against the order of the Special Magistrate refusing to quash the proceedings on the ground that the prosecution of the appellant inter alia under sections 161 and 165 of the Indian Penal Code was illegal and without jurisdiction in the absence of the sanction of the Government under section 197 of the Criminal Procedure Code and section 6 of the Prevention of Corruption Act II of 1947

facts.text: Appellant prosecuted inter alia under sections 161 and 165 of the Indian Penal Code.

anchor.surface_text: --This is an appeal by special leave against an order of the Allahabad High Court dismissing the revision petition of the appellant against the order of the Special Magistrate refusing to quash the proceedings on the ground that the prosecution of the appellant inter alia under sections 161 and 165 of the Indian Penal Code was illegal and without jurisdiction in the absence of the sanction of the Government under section 197 of the Criminal Procedure Code and section 6 of the Prevention of Corruption Act II of 1947 , hereafter referred to as the Act.

facts.text: In 1947 the appellant held the office of Regional Deputy Iron and Steel Controller, Kanpur Circle, U.P., and was a public servant.

anchor.surface_text: The material facts are these. In 1947 the appellant held the office of Regional Deputy Iron and Steel Controller, Kanpur Circle, U.P., and was a public servant.

facts.text: Police suspected the appellant to be guilty of the offences under sections 161 and 165 IPC and applied to the Deputy Magistrate, Kanpur, for a warrant of his arrest on the 22nd of October, 1947.

anchor.surface_text: The police having suspected the appellant to be guilty of the offences mentioned above applied to the Deputy Magistrate, Kanpur, for a warrant of his arrest on the 22nd of October, 1947,

facts.text: Warrant of arrest issued by Deputy Magistrate on the 23rd of October, 1947.

anchor.surface_text: and the warrant was issued on the next day.

facts.text: Appellant was arrested on the 27th of October, 1947, but was granted bail.

anchor.surface_text: The appellant was arrested on the 27th of October, 1947, but was granted bail.

facts.text: On the 26th of November, 1947, the District Magistrate cancelled his bail as the Magistrate considered that the sureties were not proper.

anchor.surface_text: On the 26th of November, 1947, the District Magistrate cancelled his bail as the Magistrate considered that the sureties were not proper.

facts.text: On the 1st of December, 1947, the Government appointed a Special Magistrate to try offences under the Act.

anchor.surface_text: On the 1st of December, 1947, the Government appointed a Special Magis- trate to try offences under the Act

facts.text: On the 1st December, 1947, the appellant was produced before the Special Magistrate and was granted bail.

anchor.surface_text: and on the 1st December, 1947, the appellant was produced before the Special Magis- trate and was granted bail.

facts.text: Police continued their investigation.

anchor.surface_text: The police continued their investigation.

facts.text: On the 6th of December, 1948, sanction was granted by the Provincial Government to prosecute the appellant inter alia under sections 161 and 165 of the Indian Penal Code.

anchor.surface_text: On the 6th of December, 1948, sanction was granted by the Provincial Government to prosecute the appel- lant inter alia under sections 161 and 165 of of the Indian Penal Code.

facts.text: On the 31st January, 1949, sanction in the same terms was granted by the Central Government.

anchor.surface_text: On the 31st January, 1949, sanction in the same terms was granted by the Central Government.

facts.text: As a result of an appeal by the appellant to the High Court of Allahabad the amount of his bail was reduced and on the 25th of March, 1949, the appellant was ordered to be put up before the Magistrate to answer the charge-sheet submitted by the prosecution.

anchor.surface_text: In the meantime as a result of an appeal made by the appellant to the High Court of Allahabad the amount of his bail was reduced and on the 25th of March, 1949, the appellant was ordered to be put up before the Magistrate to answer the charge-sheet submit- ted by the prosecution.

facts.text: Appellant argued that the Magistrate took cognizance of the offence on 22nd October 1947 when issuing the warrant for arrest, without sanction.

anchor.surface_text: On behalf of the appellant it is argued that when the warrant for his arrest was issued by the Magistrate on the 22nd of October, 1947, the Magistrate took cognizance of the offence and, as no sanction of the Government had been obtained before that day, the initiation of the proceedings against him, which began on that day without the sanction of the Government, was illegal.

facts.text: On 25th March 1949, the Magistrate issued notice under section 190 CrPC against the appellant returnable on 2nd May 1949.

anchor.surface_text: Moreover, in the present case on the 25th March, 1949, the Magistrate issued a notice under section 190 of the Criminal Procedure Code against the appellant and made it returnable on the 2nd of May, 1949.

facts.text: Court found that the Magistrate took cognizance of the offence only on 25th March 1949.

anchor.surface_text: That clearly shows that the Magistrate took cognizance of the offence only on that day and acted under section 190 of the Criminal Procedure Code.

facts.text: Special Magistrate refused to quash the proceedings.

anchor.surface_text: dismissing the revision petition of the appellant against the order of the Special Magistrate refusing to quash the proceedings

facts.text: Appellant contended that sanction of Central Government was void because not given by State Government.

anchor.surface_text: On the returnable date the appellant contended that the sanction of the Central Government was void because it was not given by the Government of the State.

facts.text: Appellant appealed to High Court and then to Privy Council after decision against him.

anchor.surface_text: On the deci- sion going against him he appealed to the High Court and to the Privy Council.
by special leave from an order of the High Court of Allahabad.

issues.text: whether the prosecution of the appellant under sections 161 and 165 of the Indian Penal Code was illegal and without jurisdiction in the absence of the sanction of the Government under section 197 of the Criminal Procedure Code and section 6 of the Prevention of Corruption Act II of 1947

anchor.surface_text: This is an appeal by special leave against an order of the Allahabad High Court dismissing the revision petition of the appellant against the order of the Special Magistrate refusing to quash the proceedings on the ground that the prosecution of the appellant inter alia under sections 161 and 165 of the Indian Penal Code was illegal and without jurisdiction in the absence of the sanction of the Government under section 197 of the Criminal Procedure Code and section 6

anchor.surface_text: section 3 of the Act which runs as follows-- An offence punishable under section 161 or section 165 of the Indian Penal Code shall be deemed to be a cogniz- able offence for the purposes of the Code of Criminal Proce- dure, 1898, notwithstanding anything to the contrary contain- ed therein. Provided that a police officer below the rank of Deputy Superintendent of Police shall not investigate any such offence without the order of a Magistrate of the first class or make any arrest therefor without a warrant.

issues.text: whether sanction under section 197 CrPC and section 6 PCA is required at the stage of taking cognizance or earlier during investigation

anchor.surface_text: The material part of section 197 of the Criminal Procedure Code provides that where any public servant who is not removable from his office save with the sanction of Government is accused of an offence alleged to have been committed by him while acting or purporting to act in the discharge of his official duty, no court shall take cognizance of such offence except with the previous sanction of the appropriate Government.

arguments.claim: Sanction of Central Government void because not given by State Government

anchor.surface_text: On the returnable date the appellant contended that the sanction of the Central Government was void because it was not given by the Government of the State.

holdings.text: The order of the Magistrate under the proviso to section 3 of the Prevention of Corruption Act is made during police investigation before taking cognizance under section 190 CrPC or section 6 PCA.

anchor.surface_text: The important point to be borne in mind is that the order of the Magistrate, which has to be obtained, is during the time the police is investigating the case and not when they have completed their investigation and are initiating the pro- ceedings against the suspected person under section 190 of the Criminal Procedure Code. The order which may be applied for and made during the police investigation by virtue of section 3 of the Act is therefore before the Magistrate has taken cognizance of the offence under section 6 of the Act or section 190 of the Criminal Procedure Code.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Textual reading of s3 proviso PCA limits police powers during investigation; harmonized with s190 CrPC as pre-cognizance stage for cognizable offences.

holdings.text: Issuing warrant for arrest under proviso to s3 PCA does not amount to taking cognizance of the offence under s190 CrPC.

anchor.surface_text: That appears to us to be the result of reading sections 3 and 6 of Act II of 1947 and section 190 of the Criminal Procedure Code read with the definition of cognizable offence in the Code. The argument of the appellant is that when the Magis- trate issued the warrant in October, 1947, he did so on taking cognizance of the offence under section 161 or 165 of the Indian Penal Code under section 190 of the Criminal Procedure Code.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Assumption that warrant requires prior cognizance unsound; s3 proviso expressly empowers during investigation of cognizable offence.

holdings.text: Sanction under s197 CrPC and s6 PCA required only at stage of taking cognizance under s190 CrPC, not during prior police investigation.

anchor.surface_text: The material part of section 197 of the Criminal Procedure Code provides that where any public servant who is not removable from his office save with the sanction of Government is accused of an offence alleged to have been committed by him while acting or purporting to act in the discharge of his official duty, no court shall take cognizance of such offence except with the previous sanction of the appropriate Government.

holdings.reasoning_summary: s197 follows s190; cognizance indicates initiation stage post-investigation; s3 proviso warrant not initiation.

holdings.text: Prosecution not illegal without prior sanction as cognizance not taken until after sanction obtained.

anchor.surface_text: Reading sections 197 and 190 of the Criminal Procedure Code and section 6 of the Act in the light of the wording of the proviso to section 3, it is therefore clear that the stage at which a warrant is asked for under the proviso to section 3 of the Act is not on cognizance of the offence by the Magistrate as contemplated by the other three sections.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Combined application of ss 3,6 PCA, 190,197 CrPC; no cognizance in 1947, sanction present by 1949 cognizance.

holdings.text: Magistrate took cognizance of the offence on 25th March 1949 upon issuing notice under s190 CrPC.

anchor.surface_text: Moreover, in the present case on the 25th March, 1949, the Magistrate issued a notice under section 190 of the Criminal Procedure Code against the appellant and made it returnable on the 2nd of May, 1949. That clearly shows that the Magistrate took cognizance of the offence only on that day and acted under section 190 of the Criminal Procedure Code.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Direct evidence from record: s190 notice issued then; prior actions were investigation-related.

holdings.text: Taking cognizance occurs when Magistrate applies mind to proceed under Chapter XIV CrPC (e.g., ss 200, 202), not for investigation actions like s156(3) order or arrest warrant.
holdings.reasoning_summary: Adopts and approves Das Gupta J's test from precedents; distinguishes Emperor v. Sourindra Mohan; applies to facts.

anchor.surface_text: Emperor v. Sourindra Mohan Chuckerbutty 1 . It is therefore necessary to determine when the Magis- trate took cognizance of the offence.

precedents.cited_proposition: certain observations on when the Magistrate took cognizance of the offence

anchor.surface_text: Emperor v. Sourindra Mohan Chuckerbutty  1 , in respect of the interpretation of the word cognizance. In that case, on the 24th April, 1909, a dacoity took place at N and on the same day the police sent up a report of the occurrence to the Sub-divisional officer of Diamond Harbour.

precedents.cited_proposition: interpretation of the word cognizance; taking cognizance does not involve any formal action or indeed action of any kind but occurs as soon as a magistrate as such applies his mind to the suspected commission of an offence
precedents.cited_holding: taking cognizance does number involve any formal action or indeed action of any kind but occurs as soon as a. magistrate as such applies his mind to the suspected commission of an offence

anchor.surface_text: Gopal Marwari v. Emperor  1 , it was observed that the word cognizanceis used in the Code to indicate the point when the Magistrate or a Judge first takes judicial notice of an offence. it is a different thing from the initiation of proceedings.

precedents.cited_proposition: the word cognizance is used in the Code to indicate the point when the Magistrate or a Judge first takes judicial notice of an offence; it is a different thing from the initiation of proceedings; condition precedent to initiation
precedents.cited_holding: the word cognizanceis used in the Code to indicate the point when the Magistrate or a Judge first takes judicial notice of an offence. it is a different thing from the initiation of proceedings. It is the condition precedent to the initiation of proceedings by the Magistrate.

anchor.surface_text: Emperor v. Sourindra Mohan Chuckerbutty  2 , it was stated by Das Gupta J. in Superintendent and Remembrancer of Legal Affairs, West Bengal v. Abani Kumar Banerjee  3  as follows -- What is taking cognizance has number been defined

precedents.citation: Superintendent and Remembrancer of Legal Affairs, West Bengal v. Abani Kumar Banerjee  3

anchor.surface_text: Superintendent and Remembrancer of Legal Affairs, West Bengal v. Abani Kumar Banerjee  3  as follows -- What is taking cognizance has number been defined in the Criminal Procedure Code and I have numberdesire to attempt to define it. It seems to me clear however that before it can be said that any magistrate has taken cognizance of any offence under section 190  1   a , Criminal Procedure Code,

precedents.case_name: Superintendent and Remembrancer of Legal Affairs, West Bengal v. Abani Kumar Banerjee
precedents.cited_proposition: meaning of taking cognizance under section 190(1)(a) CrPC; applies mind for purpose of proceeding under subsequent sections, not for ordering investigation or search warrant
precedents.cited_holding: before it can be said that any magistrate has taken cognizance of any offence under section 190 1 a , Criminal Procedure Code, he must number only have applied his mind to the contents of the petition but he must have done so for the purpose of proceeding in a particular way as indicated in the subsequent provisions of this Chapter--proceeding under section 200 and thereafter sending it for inquiry and report under section 202. When the magistrate applies his mind number for the purpose of proceeding under the subsequent sections of this Chapter, but for taking action of some other kind, e.g., ordering investigation under section 156 3 , or issuing a search warrant for the purpose of the investigation, he cannot be said to have taken cognizance of the offence.

anchor.surface_text: The important point to be borne in mind is that the order of the Magistrate, which has to be obtained, is during the time the police is investigating the case and not when they have completed their investigation and are initiating the pro- ceedings against the suspected person under section 190 of the Criminal Procedure Code. The order which may be applied for and made during the police investigation by virtue of section 3 of the Act is therefore before the Magistrate has taken cognizance of the offence under section 6 of the Act or section 190 of the Criminal Procedure Code.

dismissing the revision petition of the appellant against the order of the Special Magistrate refusing to quash the proceedings on the ground that the prosecution of the appellant inter alia under sections 161 and 165 of the Indian Penal Code was illegal and without jurisdiction in the absence of the sanction of the Government under section 107 of the Criminal Procedure Code and section 6 of the Prevention of Corruption. Act  II of 1947 , hereafter referred to as the Act.

anchor.surface_text: That appears to us to be the result of reading sections 3 and 6 of Act II of 1947 and section 190 of the Criminal Procedure Code read with the definition of cognizable offence in the Code. The argument of the appellant is that when the Magis- trate issued the warrant in October, 1947, he did so on taking cognizance of the offence under section 161 or 165 of the Indian Penal Code under section 190 of the Criminal Procedure Code.

anchor.surface_text: The material part of section 197 of the Criminal Procedure Code provides that where any public servant who is not removable from his office save with the sanction of Government is accused of an offence alleged to have been committed by him while acting or purporting to act in the discharge of his official duty, no court shall take cognizance of such offence except with the previous sanction of the appropriate Government.

Act  II of 1947 , hereafter referred to as the Act.

anchor.surface_text: Reading sections 197 and 190 of the Criminal Procedure Code and section 6 of the Act in the light of the wording of the proviso to section 3, it is therefore clear that the stage at which a warrant is asked for under the proviso to section 3 of the Act is not on cognizance of the offence by the Magistrate as contemplated by the other three sections.

Act  II of 1947 , hereafter referred to as the Act.

anchor.surface_text: Moreover, in the present case on the 25th March, 1949, the Magistrate issued a notice under section 190 of the Criminal Procedure Code against the appellant and made it returnable on the 2nd of May, 1949. That clearly shows that the Magistrate took cognizance of the offence only on that day and acted under section 190 of the Criminal Procedure Code.
